awd_titl_txt: SG: Leveraging massive song databases and deep learning to examine the mechanisms causing diversification of bird vocalizations.
awd_abstract_narration:
Bird songs provide a fascinating example of animal communication that help birds find mates, hold territories, and more. Like human language, bird songs can change over time and across the range of a given species. The evolution of song differences is thought to be an important component in the formation of new bird species. However, biologists' understanding how bird songs evolve over space and time, and what causes their evolution, is incompletely known. This project will analyze decades of field recordings made by ornithologists and birding enthusiasts, combined with existing genetic data, to test hypotheses related to the evolution of bird song in multiple species across the continental United States. It will develop software to evaluate differences in bird calls across the range of many species and integrate these data with data on genetic, geographic, and environmental variation to test hypotheses about the causes and consequences of bird song evolution. This project will involve collaboration with computer scientists and software engineers to advance the field of computational biology and "big data" analysis for biological questions. Undergraduate students will have the opportunity to participate in the research, learn important skills in computational biology, and have novel experiences inside and outside of the classroom.
 
Birds are well known for possessing a diverse array of songs and calls that mediate social behavior, reproduction, and communication. Within a single species, bird vocalizations change through space and time due to the influence of drift, selection and mate choice, but there is a relative lack of knowledge about how biogeographic history and community dynamics across larger regions influence the evolution of bird vocalizations and speciation. This project will use large datasets available both for bird vocalizations and phylogeography to analyze relationships between vocalizations, geography, history, and community composition, for multiple species, on a continental scale. The project will assess the impact that Plio-Pleistocene glacial cycles had on phylogeography and vocalizations within species and across communities and test hypotheses regarding the evolutionary drivers of song divergence. The proposed work will develop pipelines to collect massive amounts of song data, process it algorithmically, integrate it into existing pipelines for the analysis of phylogeographic data, contrast these data to environmental predictor variables, and ultimately test hypotheses of divergence. This work will provide the groundwork for the integration of phenotypic and genetic databases to investigate diversification of bird vocalization on a global scale.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Vocalizations from birds are a persistent feature of most terrestrial ecosystems. Careful observers have long noticed that individual birds have slight differences in these vocalizations; in this way bird songs are similar to most of biological traits in the sense that there is variation in these traits across a biological population or species. However, while traits such as size are easily quantified, differences in bird songs across individuals have traditionally required considerable effort to measure. Prior to this work, most researchers would convert a recording of a song to a graphic that depicts the sound wave before manually scoring differences across individuals. This process is labor intensive and only a fraction of the nearly 800,00 recordings of bird songs had been measured prior to this work. The project work trained a neural network artificial intelligence pipeline to develop a song identification pipeline. Our major results indicate that the AI pipeline is most accurate when applied to the test species (i.e., the species whose songs were used in the training of the AI) but also works well on closely related taxa. This suggests that training AI on a representative set of taxa would enable high-accuracy quantification across the different types of songbirds.

Once the AI was trained to quantify differences across song recordings from different individuals, we tried to identify factors that could be responsible for these differences. For example, in human language there are regional dialects among speakers of the same language, so it seems reasonable that geographic separation would be one factor that influenced differences in bird song vocalization. To test these hypotheses, we analyzed more than 23,000 recordings from New World sparrows and collected genetic data and information about the geographic ranges of these sparrow species in order to understand environmental differences. Our results demonstrate that a variety of factors, including the spatial and temporal separation of recordings as well as environmental variation influence the evolution of bird songs within many species. Since the patterns that we observe closely match those evident in the neutral genetic variation, it is likely that cultural drift is at least as important to the evolution of bird song as genetic drift is to the evolution of intraspecific genetic diversity. This finding is generally consistent with similar investigations conducted on other biological traits, and a great example of how AI methods can be used to supplement data collection in biological systems.
